forumNotes.author: Sha0
forumNotes.content: > exsisting xp (prosp2) that I boot from usb with the usboot method.. > > I want to learn how I can make this load into ram. I think is is possible somehow, right? * Install WinVBlock into your existing XP Pro SP2. * Shrink the partition to a size suitable for being loaded into the amount of RAM you have in mind. * Capture an image file containing the sectors from the beginning of the disk through to the end of the partition. * Put this image file anywhere you like and boot it as a RAM disk using either **MEMDISK** or GRUB4DOS' **map --mem**

forumNotes.author: Sha0
forumNotes.content:
> ...recommend a suitable program that you know will work for this? I enjoy **DD** . What you want is a "raw" (sector-by-sector) image file. DD from Linux works nicely. [DD for Windows](http://www.chrysocome.net/dd "External link") works too, but it's a Bad Idea to capture your image if you are booted from the disk you are capturing the image from. That is, it'd be best to boot from some other Windows if you are going to use DD for Windows. ``` dd if=\\.\PhysicalDrive1 of=zoso_win.hdd --progress ```
Other folks might have other suggestions; there are many options for capturing such an image file. > ...I have booted a few .iso files but not image files as of yet so I will read up on that also. Actually, an .ISO *is* an image file; a CD/DVD image file rather than an HDD image file. You can capture an .ISO from a CD using DD for Windows with: ``` dd if=\\.\CdRom0 of=some.iso bs=2048 --progress ``` An .ISO can be as simple as an ISO9660 filesystem, or it can be a "hybrid" image with other filesystems, as well.
